title: Erewhon’s Secrets
excerpt: Japanese utopians. Corporate glow-ups. $400 smoothies. The strange history of the world’s most cultish grocery store.

title: H-E-B Forever
excerpt: Nobody in America loves anything as much as Texans love H-E-B

title: The Bizarre Story of Piggly Wiggly, the First Self-Service Grocery Store
Florida’s favorite grocery store seeks to be uncomplicated in a complicated
excerpt: Could you build a company like Publix today?

title: The Man Who’s Going to Save Your Neighborhood Grocery Store
excerpt: American food supplies are increasingly channeled through a handful of big companies: Amazon, Walmart, FreshDirect, Blue Apron. What do we lose when local supermarkets go under? A lot -- and Kevin Kelley wants to stop that.

title: Trader Joe's: The Anti-Grocer
excerpt: The grocer created a cult brand with sales of $16B+ a year by doing the opposite of industry best-practices (from wages to product to ads).

title: Should Print Circulars Stay or Go?
excerpt: Kroger is following in the footsteps of Giant Eagle, attempting to phase out its print inserts in newspapers and mailed to homes in favor of digital alternatives.

title: As Dollar Stores Proliferate, Some Communities Say No
excerpt: More than 70 proposed dollar stores have been rejected since 2019, a report shows. It’s a small number compared with those that opened but evidence of opposition to the industry.

title: Salvage stores achieve sales growth by selling ‘unsellable’ goods
excerpt: In an inflationary era when customers are increasingly strapped for cash and hunting for discounts, a category of ultra-low-priced grocers that sell the unsellable is growing in popularity. Do you expect mainstream grocers to change their protocols for "unsellable" CPG items if inflation persists?

title: The hidden makers of Costco’s Kirkland Signature and Trader Joe’s O’s | CNN Business
excerpt: Store brands are shrouded in secrecy. Who makes them?

title: Business school grads and quants are winning the battle to create the next
excerpt: These days my Instagram feed feels more like QVC than a social network. And many of these companies are enjoying tremendous success pitching natural deodorants, unique underwear, creative candles, glam glasses, stunning shoes -- all manner of well-crafted microbrands. We’re witnessing a cambrian explosion of new consumer startups.
